A horizontal circular platform with rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub p " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> rotates freely without friction on a vertical axis. A small motor-driven wheel that is used to rotate the platform is mounted under the platform and touches it. The wheel has radius <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and touches the platform a distance <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from the vertical axis of the platform, as shown above. The platform starts at rest, and the wheel exerts a constant horizontal force of magnitude <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> tangent to the wheel until the platform reaches an angular speed <math alttext="omega sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> after time <math alttext="delta t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. During time <math alttext="delta t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the wheel stays in contact with the platform without slipping.

(a) Derive an expression for the angular speed <math alttext="omega sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of the platform. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="I sub p " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="delta t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(b) Determine an expression for the kinetic energy of the platform at the moment it reaches angular speed <math alttext="omega sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="I sub p " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="delta t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(c) Derive an expression for the angular speed <math alttext="omega sub W" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>W</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of the wheel when the platform has reached angular speed <math alttext="omega sub p " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="omega sub p " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

When the platform is spinning at angular speed <math alttext="omega sub p " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the motor-driven wheel is removed. A student holds a disk directly above and concentric with the platform, as shown above. The disk has the same rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> as the platform. The student releases the disk from rest, and the disk falls onto the platform. After a short time, the disk and platform are observed to be rotating together at angular speed <math alttext="omega sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Derive an expression for <math alttext="omega sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="omega sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="I sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

A student now uses the rotating platform <math alttext="open parenthesis, I sub p equals 3.1 kilograms times meters squared, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>3.1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>·</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub U" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of an unknown object about a vertical axis that passes through the object’s center of mass. The platform is rotating at an initial angular speed <math alttext="omega sub i" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> when the unknown object is dropped with its center of mass directly above the center of the platform. The platform and object are observed to be rotating together at angular speed <math alttext="omega sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Trials are repeated for different values of <math alttext="omega sub i" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. A graph of <math alttext="omega sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of <math alttext="omega sub i" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown on the axes below.

(e)

i. On the graph on the previous page, draw a best-fit line for the data.

ii. Using the straight line, calculate the rotational inertia of the unknown object <math alttext="I sub U" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> about a vertical axis passing through its center of mass.

(f) The kinetic energy of the spinning platform before the object is dropped on it is <math alttext="K sub i " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The total kinetic energy of the platform-object system when it reaches angular speed <math alttext="omega sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="K sub f " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the followingexpressions is true?

<math alttext="K sub f, is less than K sub i " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="K sub f, equals K sub i " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="K sub f, is greater than K sub i" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

Justify your answer.

(g) One of the students observes that the center of mass of the object is not actually aligned with the axis of the platform. Is the experimental value of <math alttext="I sub U " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> obtained in part (e) greater than, less than, or equal to the actual value of the rotational inertia of the unknown object about a vertical axis that passes through its center of mass?
